body:
Sure it's simpler than trying to match the `(busy)` part...
thanks.

I'm sorry... I think I'm tired and I better go home... (rebased -f pushed to avoid 3 one line commits...)
I'll try to do something nicer later like
`set_document_title_idle`
`set_document_title_busy`
`set_document_title_unsaved` ...
OK, this looks good after your fixes.  Thanks @minrk for catching those!  I'm merging now.

Sorry I am late to the party, but I _don't_ think we should use the Window title for status information.  It is just not the place for dynamic information and I don't want to get into the habit of doing this.

I don't understand the reasons for your objection but I can emphasize that it's a big productivity gain for me. Especially when working with multiple notebooks switching back to check whether a computation completed is much more disruptive than having a quick glance at the title bar. Of course, you may chide me for being so impatient but I don't think I'll get rid of that habit easily.

Well, I don't think we should be going overboard, but I'd found myself already a number of times wanting precisely this very feature, and I do find it super useful: it's unobtrusive and lets you know at a quick glance, from a pile of open browser tabs, which one to return to.  It's the browser equivalent of terminal bells.

Gmail/gchat use this same idea to mark activity in a browser tab and I always have found it useful, despite me being fairly allergic to anything that blinks/moves in my visual field.

How else would you suggest we approach this?  Within javascript we  don't have the right to call any local (growl-like) notification mechanism, and those tend to be even more intrusive in general (with popups and stuff).  I'm happy to discuss it further, but honestly this one seems to me like a good, valid use of the titlebar as the least-intrusive solution to an actual problem.  I don't foresee anything else going into the titlebar in the long run,  though, so I don't think you need to worry about this being the first step in a problematic feature creep in that direction.

I can try to make it configurable for people who really don't like it, and the only other thing I see that could go in `document.title` it a small `*`showing that it's curently not saved.
One other idea would be to change `favicon` depending on state smth like red=busy, black=idle, blue=read-only (even if i'm even more sceptical on this one)

On Thu, Dec 1, 2011 at 2:43 PM, Bussonnier Matthias
reply@reply.github.com
wrote:

> I can try to make it configurable for people who really don't like it,

I don't like falling back on "let's make it configurable" as a way of
resolving all disagreements.  I would much rather we make a decision
that works for everyone, even if that decision is not my first choice.

> and the only other thing I see that could go in `document.title` it a small `*`showing that it's curently not saved.

But that is exactly the reason I am opposed to this in the first
place.  I _don't_ want us to view document.title as a place to put
dynamic content and expand its usage for other types of notifications
such as the saved status.

> One other idea would be to change `favicon` depending on state smth like red=busy, black=idle, blue=read-only (even if i'm even more sceptical on this one)

Again, it is just not the place for dynamic content.

Cheers,

Brian

> ---
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
> https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/1084#issuecomment-2983341

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

On Thu, Dec 1, 2011 at 2:49 PM, Brian E. Granger
reply@reply.github.com
wrote:

> I don't like falling back on "let's make it configurable" as a way of
> resolving all disagreements.  I would much rather we make a decision
> that works for everyone, even if that decision is not my first choice.

Totally agreed, we shouldn't let the interface proliferate into
insanity with config options.

> > and the only other thing I see that could go in `document.title` it a small `*`showing that it's curently not saved.
> 
> But that is exactly the reason I am opposed to this in the first
> place.  I _don't_ want us to view document.title as a place to put
> dynamic content and expand its usage for other types of notifications
> such as the saved status.
> 
> > One other idea would be to change `favicon` depending on state smth like red=busy, black=idle, blue=read-only (even if i'm even more sceptical on this one)
> 
> Again, it is just not the place for dynamic content.

I actually think we're OK, because I would also have shot down both of
those proposals:
- the 'dirty/usnaved' information doesn't belong there because the
  only place you can take action on that (to save) is by having the
  worksheet open.  So the place where you need to know whether it needs
  saving is in the worksheet itself, we can think of a good place to
  show this state, but the title is certainly not.
- the icon changing: that goes a bit too far, and starts getting into
  visual gimmick territory.

So on this particular topic, I'd say the 'busy' indicator does serve a
valid purpose, but I reiterate it's _not_ the 'first of many' such
things.  It's useful because it does show you the one thing you want
to know about a kernel without opening its tab manually: "is it
finished so I can go look at my results, or should I keep doing
something else over here?".  Because it lets you answer that question
at a glance, without otherwise disturbing your workflow and that
information _has_ value when you're in a different tab (in contrast to
the dirty info, for example), then I think it's a valid piece of data
to put in the title, and probably the only piece of dynamic info that
should go there.

Note that I'm not trying to quash your concerns, we should definitely
discuss this one further; just trying to show what I think are valid
reasons to justify that decision, and also to not keep adding other
stuff there.

Fernando,

On Thu, Dec 1, 2011 at 5:09 PM, Fernando Perez
reply@reply.github.com
wrote:

> On Thu, Dec 1, 2011 at 2:49 PM, Brian E. Granger
> reply@reply.github.com
> wrote:

> > dynamic content and expand its usage for other types of notifications

> > Again, it is just not the place for dynamic content.
> 
> I actually think we're OK, because I would also have shot down both of
> those proposals:
> - the 'dirty/usnaved' information doesn't belong there because the
>   only place you can take action on that (to save) is by having the
>   worksheet open.  So the place where you need to know whether it needs
>   saving is in the worksheet itself, we can think of a good place to
>   show this state, but the title is certainly not.
> - the icon changing: that goes a bit too far, and starts getting into
>   visual gimmick territory.

OK, I still not thrilled about the "Busy" indicator, but as long as
there is an understanding that this is the only thing we will put
there, then I am OK with this remaining in.

Cheers,

Brian

> So on this particular topic, I'd say the 'busy' indicator does serve a
> valid purpose, but I reiterate it's _not_ the 'first of many' such
> things.  It's useful because it does show you the one thing you want
> to know about a kernel without opening its tab manually: "is it
> finished so I can go look at my results, or should I keep doing
> something else over here?".  Because it lets you answer that question
> at a glance, without otherwise disturbing your workflow and that
> information _has_ value when you're in a different tab (in contrast to
> the dirty info, for example), then I think it's a valid piece of data
> to put in the title, and probably the only piece of dynamic info that
> should go there.
> 
> Note that I'm not trying to quash your concerns, we should definitely
> discuss this one further; just trying to show what I think are valid
> reasons to justify that decision, and also to not keep adding other
> stuff there.

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

On Fri, Dec 2, 2011 at 9:15 AM, Brian E. Granger
reply@reply.github.com
wrote:

> OK, I still not thrilled about the "Busy" indicator, but as long as
> there is an understanding that this is the only thing we will put
> there, then I am OK with this remaining in.

It  may grow on you ;)  (I'm in Moritz's camp here, I find it
extremely useful and had already missed it on more than one occasion).

But thanks for the solid feedback, this is how we build a good idea of
our 'design boundaries' to build a really good interface.
